title.narrative: # of women and youth involved in politics who feel they are able to participate in decision-making processes

description.narrative: # of women and youth involved in politics who feel they are able to participate in decision-making processes

comment.narrative: According to the collected data, only 18 out of a sampled 80 representing 23% of women feel they are able and have what it takes to meaningfully participate in decision making processes. These argued that while there are existing interventions targeting women participation in policy and decision making processes, they are not systemically connected and often key actors engage at the tail end and not working through the whole continuum. In as far as policy implementation is concerned, in addition to women leaders having technical expertise they also need to intervene along the whole continuum. These also assert that if women leaders were engaged in all processes of decision making, they would be in position to participate and meaningfully influence these processes to ensure that women issues are integrated from the onset. This is problematic as it then becomes almost impossible to influence decisions at the tail end of the financial process.

comment.narrative: At the time of the baseline survey, no lobbying and advocacy activities had been undertaken to make the political system more inclusive in 2021. Ruth Asiimwe of Uganda Youth Network noted that because of Government restrictions on engagements resulting from the COVID19 pandemic, engagements with policy makers and power holders aimed at lobbying them for action aimed at making the political system more inclusive have been curtailed. The Chairperson of the Women’s league for DP also observes that the initially intended interventions have also been hard hit given the economic crisis that COVID19 has plunged the global economy in.

title.narrative: # of inclusive policy-making processes (at national level)

description.narrative: # of inclusive policy-making processes (at national level)

comment.narrative: Currently, there is no inclusive policy making process at the National level. This is because of the nature of the legislative process in the Country where all policy processes are initiated by the Cabinet and passed by Parliament, in accordance with Article 111 of the Constitution. Whereas the process in Parliament can be seen as inclusive, major sections of the society that are normally affected by a given policy are mostly left out. Even the consultations about a given policy are done in line with the proposals of Cabinet with little room for influence by those to be affected. Even without a formal inclusive policy making process, there have been efforts by stakeholders to consult and incorporate views of those who are impacted by the policy although these have been more evident at amendments as opposed to passing of Acts.

These electoral reform proposals targeted the Presidential Elections Act, Parliamentary Elections Act, and Local Government Act.
